;;S;;NIFFY TYPES 蔑视“全球南方”的概念，近年来这个概念已经成为一种流行文化。它的不足之处是显而易见的：三个词永远无法描述从摩洛哥到马来西亚及其他地区的 100 多个国家的复杂性。但这句话已被乔·拜登、伊曼纽尔·马克龙和习近平采用。

;最简单的定义是它指的是大多数非西方国家。它的使用还表明新兴经济体希望在全球事务上拥有更多权力，并且往往对西方政策持批评态度。因此，据说南半球国家对加沙战争感到愤怒，并对西方在乌克兰、covid-19和气候政策方面的决定感到不满。美国智库昆西负责任治国研究所的萨朗·希多尔 (Sarang Shidore) 表示，“全球南方的存在与其说是一个连贯的、有组织的群体，不如说是一个地缘政治事实。”

;;我;;N;乌克兰对安东诺夫斯基大桥发动火箭袭击的准备阶段，安东诺夫斯基大桥是通往被占领地区的重要道路在第聂伯河东岸的赫尔松市，安全官员仔细研究了一系列特别报告。那是 2022 年夏天，俄罗斯严重依赖这座桥为其第聂伯河以西的部队提供补给。这些报告包含对两件事的研究：摧毁这座桥是否会导致俄罗斯士兵或其家人感到恐慌？更重要的是，乌克兰政府如何通过创造“特定的信息环境”来最大限度地打击士气？

;

;Sviatoslav Hnizdovsky 就是这样的基辅开放思想研究所 (;OMI;) 的创始人介绍了他的研究机构通过人工智能 (;AI;) 生成这些评估所做的工作。算法对俄罗斯社交媒体内容和社会经济数据进行了筛选，涉及从酒精消费和人口流动到在线搜索和消费者行为等各种内容。 ;AI; 将任何变化与俄罗斯“忠诚主义者”和自由主义者对其国家士兵潜在困境的不断变化的情绪联系起来。

;

;赫尼兹多夫斯基先生表示，这项高度敏感的工作将继续影响乌克兰关于战争进程的重要决策。这包括未来可能对俄罗斯;刻赤大桥;，这是俄罗斯和克里米亚之间唯一的直接陆地连接。

;;

;配备 ChatGPT

;

;乌克兰在军事上落后于俄罗斯，越来越多地寻求利用;人工智能;优势，作者：;以多种方式利用技术;。一名参与武器开发的乌克兰上校表示，无人机设计者通常将 Chat;GPT; 视为工程理念的“起点”，例如减少俄罗斯干扰脆弱性的新技术。这位要求匿名的上校表示，;人工智能;的另一个军事用途是识别目标。

;

;作为士兵而且军事博主明智地对自己的帖子变得更加谨慎，简单地搜索有关部队位置的任何线索已经变得不那么有效。然而，通过摄取大量图像和文本，<小>;人工智能;模型可以找到潜在的线索，将它们拼接在一起，然后推测武器系统或部队编队的可能位置。 Molfar 是一家在第聂伯罗和基辅设有办事处的情报公司，该公司分析师 Maksym Zrazhevsky 表示，将这种“拼图”方法与;AI;结合使用，通常每天都能找到两到五个有价值的目标。一旦被发现，这些情报就会迅速传递给乌克兰军队，导致一些目标被摧毁。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;AI 协助定位; 以其他方式。 SemanticForce 是一家立陶宛公司，在基辅和乌克兰西部城市捷尔诺波尔设有办事处，该公司开发的模型可以响应文本提示，审查在线或上传的文本和图像。 SemanticForce 的许多客户在商业上使用该系统来监控公众对其品牌的看法。然而，莫尔法使用该模型来绘制俄罗斯军队可能士气低落和补给不足的地区，这可能使他们成为较软的目标。 ;AI; 在图片中寻找线索，包括无人机镜头以及社交媒体中士兵的怒吼。

;

;它还使用偷偷摸摸的代理人拼凑出有关俄罗斯军事弱点的线索。为此，Molfar 使用 SemanticForce 的 ;AI; 生成有关俄罗斯志愿者团体活动的报告，这些志愿者团体为前线最需要的部门筹集资金并准备护理包。莫法尔说，这些算法可以很好地丢弃潜在的误导性机器人帖子。 （带有令人不快的政治反复无常的账户就是一个提示。）该公司的分析师有时会使用隐藏电话来源的软件来增强这种情报，以便假装是渴望贡献的俄罗斯人的工作人员可以给俄罗斯志愿者团体打电话。 。该公司 45 多名分析师中，有 10 名负责目标定位工作，并且免费为乌克兰军队提供服务。

;

;然后是反情报工作。 ;人工智能;的使用帮助乌克兰间谍抓捕者识别出直到最近担任国家安全与国防委员会(;NSDC;)秘书的奥列克西·丹尼洛夫(Oleksiy Danilov)所说的“容易背叛”的人。乌克兰前信息政策副部长德米特罗·佐洛图欣 (Dmytro Zolotukhin) 表示，通过拍摄基础设施和军事资产的地理定位照片赚钱的提议经常发送到乌克兰手机。他本人最近收到了一封这样的短信。他补充道，尝试这个“情报服务市场”的人经常会被乌克兰的 ;SBU; 情报机构逮捕。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;使用 <乌克兰反情报机构利用美国公司 Palantir 的人工智能技术，寻找不同数据池中的联系。例如，想象一下，一名负债累累的离婚者，面临着失去公寓和孩子监护权的风险，他开设了一个外国银行账户，并在后来被导弹袭击的地点附近被发现携带手机。除了这种点连接之外，;AI;还执行“社交网络分析”。比如说，如果假设的离婚者与俄罗斯有很强的个人联系，并且已经开始接听某人的电话，而该人的手机使用情况表明其社会地位较高，那么;人工智能;可能会增加他的风险评分。

;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-121tnhw e1tt35bk0">;十多年来，;AI; 对网络节点之间交互的评估结果令人印象深刻。 2013 年为阿富汗内政部提供咨询的前英国情报官员克里斯蒂安·古斯塔夫森 (Kristian Gustafson) 讲述了一名为塔利班权贵运送大量现金的快递员被抓获的经历。他说，他们随后的电话“照亮了整个图表”。从那时起，计算“中介中心性”（影响力的衡量标准）等算法的进步，正如另一位前情报官员所说，让那些日子看起来“相当原始”。

;

;此外，网络分析有助于乌克兰调查人员识别违反对俄罗斯制裁的人。消息人士称，通过将船舶登记处的数据与其他地方保存的财务记录连接起来，该软件可以“揭开公司面纱”。佐洛图欣表示，黑客正在向乌克兰机构提供“绝对巨大”的被盗商业数据缓存。这对于打击破坏制裁行为来说是一个福音。

;

;构造函数

;

; ;AI ;的使用已经发展了一段时间。乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基 (Volodymyr Zelensky) 于 2019 年 11 月呼吁大力推动该技术在国家安全中的应用。结果是由 ;NSDC; 构建和运行的具有战略意义的模型，该模型可以摄取文本、统计数据、照片和视频。 ;NSDC; 的参谋长安德烈·齐乌兹 (Andriy Ziuz) 表示，该中心被称为威胁评估运营中心 (;COTA;)，提供广泛的信息，其中一些信息是黑客获取的。该模型跟踪价格、电话使用、移民、贸易、能源、政治、外交和军事发展，直至修理店的武器。

;

; ;COTA ;的运营商将此模型称为“构造函数”。这是因为它还吸收较小模型的输出，例如 Palantir 的软件和 Delta，后者是支持乌克兰军队机动决策的战场软件。 ;NSDC; 的首席技术专家 Mykola Dobysh 表示，;COTA; 的“大局”输出为高级官员提供了敏感问题上的指导，包括动员政策。丹尼洛夫先生指出，泽伦斯基先生已在 130 多次场合听取过关于 ;COTA; 评估的简报，其中一次是在俄罗斯全面入侵当天的上午 10 点。 ;COTA; 的部分（或“电路”）的访问权限提供给其他一些团体，包括保险公司、外交部和美国能源部。

;

;乌克兰的;人工智能;努力受益于其社会为战争贡献数据的广泛意愿。公民将可能与国家国防相关的带有地理标记的照片上传到名为 Diia（乌克兰语“行动”）的政府应用程序中。许多企业向位于利沃夫的 Mantis Analytics 公司提供运营数据，包括延迟交货、呼叫中心活动以及防盗警报的触发等。该平台社会功能评估的接收者包括国防部和寻求以更好的方式部署自身安全资源的公司。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这一切最终将产生多大的影响目前还不清楚。零线的埃文·普拉特 (Evan Platt) 是基辅的一个<小>;非政府组织;，为部队提供装备，并花时间在前线研究战斗力，他将乌克兰对<小>;人工智能;的使用描述为“亮点” ”。但也有一些担忧。一是对某些<小>;人工智能;安全应用程序的热情可能会转移资源，而这些资源原本可以在其他地方带来更大的收益。对;AI;的过度信任是另一个风险，市场上的一些模型肯定被夸大了。更戏剧性的是，;人工智能;可能会对乌克兰的战场表现产生净负面影响吗？

;

;一些人这么认为。其中之一是约翰·阿奎拉（John Arquilla），他是加利福尼亚州海军研究生院的名誉教授，撰写了有影响力的战争书籍，并为五角大楼领导人提供了建议。乌克兰最大的成功出现在战争初期，当时分散的小型单位网络被鼓励即兴发挥。他认为，如今，乌克兰的<小>;人工智能;“构建过程”正在集中决策，扼杀“边缘”的创意火花。他的评估值得商榷。但至少，它强调了人类判断在如何使用任何技术方面的重要性。 ;■;

;;R;;美国的入侵;已将乌克兰变成世界上地雷最严重的国家。在赫尔松和哈尔科夫，俄罗斯士兵撤退时留下了雷区。他们不仅埋设地雷来保卫自己的阵地，还利用地雷扰乱乌克兰的农业生产。俄罗斯的一种火箭系统（称为“zemledeliye”或“农业”）可将地雷投掷到距离发射器 15 公里的地方。农业是乌克兰经济的支柱：2021年农产品出口价值277亿美元，占出口总额的40%以上。但据 ;NASA; 称，自 2022 年 2 月以来，乌克兰 7.5% 的农田目前尚未使用。国防部地雷行动局统计负责人叶夫海尼·祖巴列夫斯基上校表示，人员伤亡也造成了影响：170名农民被杀，几乎占因地雷或未爆弹药造成的平民死亡的20%。随着春播的到来，正在做什么？

;

;当俄罗斯入侵开始时，只有四家机构被授权在乌克兰开展排雷行动，除了军队和政府机构。如今，这个数字已达到 29 个，还有 19 个正在获取必要的许可证。但排雷人员仍然不知所措。适当的清理工作既困难又昂贵：团队首先会采访当地人并寻找线索，例如可能表明存在地雷或未爆炸炮弹的弹坑，然后再携带探测设备和防护装备进入。 Nibulon 是乌克兰一家大型谷物出口商，拥有自己的排雷部门，只向农民收取费用。即便如此，每公顷排雷的成本也超过 5,000 美元。尽管有政府补贴，但这对许多农民来说成本太高。 Nibulon政府关系负责人Mykhailo Rizak说，有些人已经购买或租用了远离前线的土地。他感叹道，其他人已经把事情掌握在自己手中了。

;我们的论文引起了很大争议，其中关于堕胎的一章进一步加剧了争议。我们中的一位与斯蒂芬·杜布纳 (Stephen Dubner) 合着的畅销书《魔鬼经济学》于 2005 年出版。对于许多人来说，对我们的假设做出政治反应比评估它是否正确更重要。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;当时可用的数据强烈支持我们的假设。例如，我们表明，在美国最高法院做出使堕胎在全国范围内合法化的裁决《罗伊诉韦德案》之前，五个堕胎合法化的州的犯罪率开始下降得更快。我们记录了堕胎率高和低的州的犯罪多年来遵循几乎相同的趋势，然后只有在合法堕胎的出生群体达到犯罪年龄后才突然持续出现分歧。与我们的理论一致，从揭示犯罪者年龄的逮捕数据来看，犯罪率下降集中在堕胎合法化后出生的人中。

;

;当然，这些数据模式并不构成一个开放和封闭的案例。尚未针对该主题进行随机实验。我们也没有通过错误地标记我们的一个表格中的一个规范中包含的一组控制变量来帮助我们自己的案例 - 这是一个令人遗憾的错误（后来更正），导致一些人驳回了论文的所有发现。 《经济学人》是对我们的研究结果提出最强烈和持续怀疑的声音之一，它曾在三个场合撰写过有关我们研究的文章（最近一次是;上个月;），每次都采取批评和轻蔑的立场。

;

;我们承认，理性的人可能会对我们最初论文中的研究结果的说服力有不同意见。该分析是回顾性的，人们总是担心研究人员会精挑细选他们的发现，或者这些模式的出现可能只是纯粹的巧合。

;

;然而，我们的假设有一些独特之处，它允许对更接近科学方法理想的理论进行第二次检验。从实施堕胎到受影响群体达到犯罪年龄之间存在很长的滞后期。因此，我们在 2001 年发表第一篇学术论文时就已经可以对我们的理论对未来犯罪的预测做出强有力的预测。事实上，在那篇论文的最后，我们做出了以下预测：“当大约 20 年后达到稳定状态时，堕胎的影响将大约是迄今为止所感受到的影响的两倍。我们的结果表明，在其他条件相同的情况下，堕胎合法化将导致未来二十年犯罪率每年持续下降 1%。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;很少见 - 几乎这在学术经济学中是史无前例的，能够做出可检验的预测，然后在几十年后回过头来实际检验它。这就是我们在 2020 年发表的;论文;中所做的。我们的方法很简单：模仿我们原始论文中报告的规范，但将时间段限制为样本外的年份，即原始数据结束后的年份。

;

;结果令人震惊地证实了我们的预测。对于我们在 2001 年最初的论文中提出的七种不同分析中的每一种，接下来二十年数据的结果至少与我们最初数据集中的结果一样强大，并且在大多数规范中甚至更强。这包括我们 2001 年论文的主要批评者所称的“关键”测试，该测试表明，任何出生队列时的堕胎率与该队列几年后在 15 岁至 15 岁之间的特定年龄逮捕率呈负相关。 24，同时完美控制影响特定州和特定年份犯罪的任何其他因素。我们认为，如果没有随机实验，这是可以提供的最令人信服的证据之一。

;

;隐含的规模我们所说的影响是巨大的。如果您查看整个样本，就会发现堕胎率高的州的暴力犯罪率下降了 62.2 个百分点，而堕胎率低的州的暴力犯罪率则上升了 3.1%。

;

;虽然学术界并未完全接受我们的假设，但所有人都同意，如果我们的论文不正确，那么对于 20 世纪 90 年代初开始的美国犯罪率大幅下降就没有可行的解释。事实上，甚至没有一个有争议的理论可以取代堕胎与犯罪的联系。暴露于环境中的铅也许是下一个最好的假设。但正如我们在 2020 年论文中所表明的，当同时控制环境铅和堕胎时，堕胎系数仍然很大，而环境铅系数则大大降低并失去统计显着性。

;

;我们似乎可以公平地问，为什么尽管有强有力的支持证据，但我们 2020 年论文的任何发现都没有学术上的矛盾，并且支持堕胎与犯罪之间的联系 ;国际证据;，因此许多观察家仍然对这一假设持怀疑态度。毫不奇怪，那些在犯罪率大幅下降期间靠打击犯罪谋生的人并不热衷于得出这样的结论：他们的方法——无论是更多的警察、更多的监禁还是特定的社会计划——无论它们多么重要，都不是犯罪率下降的主导因素。 。另一种可能的解释是，不同政治派别的人们都对我们的结论感到不安。许多人希望我们的假设不成立，也许没有认识到核心发现是，当女性能够控制自己的生育能力时，她们孩子的生活成果会大大提高。

;

;;I;;T HAS BEEN; a few days since a 250kg Russian glide bomb landed in Iryna Tymokhyna's courtyard on 23rd August Street, and it is fair to say she is not happy.这位 60 岁的老人坐在公园的长椅上（后来变成了她的客厅），咒骂弗拉基米尔·普京和她认为仍在帮助他的少数哈尔科夫居民。她说，她的公寓布满灰尘和碎玻璃；她的邻居被送往医院，一名路过的自行车快递员被杀。 “If it was up to me, I would shoot the bastards...and I'd wipe Belgorod [the closest Russian city] off the face of the earth while I was at it.”

;;
;;
;

;Ms Tymokhyna's sharp language is striking for the fact she was born in Russia, and most of her relatives still live there. But her outrage is far from unique in a 1.3m-person city now living through ;an airborne terror; mostly originating from the region just across the border.

;Russia stepped up its bombardment of Kharkiv in December, around the time that ;problems with American military assistance; began to make headlines. Since then, the city has been on the receiving end of more ballistic missiles than at any time since the start of the war. Drone assaults have become more frequent: they fly faster and higher, and have a carbon wing-coating that makes shooting them down harder. But the March 27th attack on 23rd August Street was perhaps the pivotal moment, marking the first time a glide bomb, launched from a plane and capable of travelling tens of kilometres to devastating effect, had been used against Ukraine's second city.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The attack came just five days after a missile barrage destroyed almost all of Kharkiv's power-generation capacity. It has been followed by more than a week of operations using glide bombs, missiles and drones, killing at least 16 and injuring another 50. There was a sinister evolution in tactics too, with “double-tap” strikes (repeated shots on the same position) that appeared to target first responders. The escalation had military sources in Kyiv suggesting that Russia has resolved to make the city a “grey zone”, uninhabitable for civilians.

;

;The man with responsibility for keeping Kharkiv running pushes back strongly against that hypothesis. In an interview conducted at a secret location in the industrial quarter, the mayor, Ihor Terekhov, says his city has no intention of giving up. Things were worse ;at the start of the war;, he argues, when all but 300,000 of the pre-war population of 2m fled. “How can you make a city like this a grey zone? People won't leave, because they have already left, then returned. They have been tortured enough already.” Yes, the challenge of powering up a city without power stations or working transformers was difficult, but they have managed it. “If I told you how we did it, that too would be targeted.” But many of the city's problems could be solved if the West provided capable air defence systems or F-16s that could push back the fighter jets carrying the new bombs. ;The Economist; understands that Russia destroyed some of the Western-supplied Patriot air-defence units that Ukraine had been using to protect cities like Kharkiv.

;

;Russia's exact intentions are not clear at this stage, though there are clear signs that it is preparing for a major summer offensive. A Ukrainian source with knowledge of the intelligence picture said Russia is currently training six divisions (approximately 120,000 troops) in eastern Siberia. On April 3rd President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia would mobilise a further 300,000 in June. Kharkiv is one of several possible directions for a future assault. It is not the most likely, but it has already been heavily trailed in Russian media. That might indicate a Kremlin information campaign to frighten Kharkiv residents. Or it could be a nod in the direction of a pro-war camp agitating for a fiercer response to Ukraine's frequent attacks on Belgorod,  which are also causing unease in Western circles. In March, Vladimir Putin talked about the creation of a “buffer zone” on Ukraine's border.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;A military operation to seize Kharkiv would be a tall order for Russia. The last time it tried, in 2022 when the city was much more poorly defended, it failed spectacularly. Taking the city would require breaking through Ukrainian defences and encircling it, which Russia is nowhere near being able to do; establishing air superiority, which is not a given; and winning a bloody urban campaign. “There's a strong chance they would not succeed with any of that,” says Andriy Zagorodnyuk, a Ukrainian expert and former defence minister. For others, the fear remains that the Russians will turn nastier when they realise they can't get what they want. “They won't be able to take Kharkiv, but destroy it—perhaps,” says Denys Yaroslavsky, a local businessman turned special-forces reconnaissance commander. “We'd be talking about something of the order of Aleppo.”

;

;Some have already taken the hint and packed their bags. Iryna Voichuk, a journalist and former doctor, left for Europe at the end of March, shortly after the glide bombs began to hit. Her nerves could no longer take it. Leaving the city felt like leaving a friend behind, she says: “I was happy to live there despite the dangers, but that changed when a missile landed 100m away from my flat.” Much of Kharkiv's commerce vanished in 2022 along with its richest inhabitants. The energy shortage and military escalation are testing the resolve of the enterprises that are left. Among them, there has so far been no exodus or panic besides a few isolated cases, insists Yury Sapronov, one of the few big businessmen left in the city. “I can't say that Kharkiv is suddenly going to benefit from a massive influx of investment, since we can't move the Russian border. But we will survive and small businesses can even prosper from internal demand.”

;

;If others have written Kharkiv off, those inside the city have yet to receive the memo. Urban life continues in spite of the dozen daily air-raid warnings. Families walk in the city's central park despite the missiles that occasionally land nearby. Kids play football next to a military facility. The sense of digging in is perhaps best summed up by the city's decision to start building its schools underground. The first of these, located in the western Industrialna district, will open this month after the spring holidays. The facility, which cost around 100m hryvnia ($2.5m), is entered via a single blast hatch that sticks out incongruously from a sports field. The school is built with reinforced concrete that goes several metres underground, and should survive anything Russia throws at it. Already all 900 spots in the first intake have been reserved.

;

;Ms Tymokhyna, who offers ;The Economist; tea in her park-bench living room, says she is happy to lend a hand with any additional digging that is needed. The two years of bombs and missiles have had an impact on her health, and her nerves are shattered. For two months at the beginning of the war she lived in a tent. But, she says, there is nothing she would not do to defend the free country that for 43 years has been her home. “I'm 60 years old, but I'm ready with my spade to go wherever I'm needed,” she says. “Make Molotov cocktails, acid, whatever it takes. Ukraine is everything to me. If the Russians dare to come here, I'll find them. They won't have a hope of staying in the realm of the living.”;■;

;If you think the billionaire and his firm are having a rough time, spare a thought for their once-white-hot imitators. Three years ago, as Mr Musk showed that ;EV;-making could be a trillion-dollar business, investors scrambled to back the newcomers promising to be the next Tesla.那年早些时候上市的两家美国初创公司正像他们的汽车一样迅速加速。 Lucid Motors成立于2007年，市值超过900亿美元；两年后创建的 Rivian 的市值达到约 1500 亿美元。每辆车的价值都超过了福特，后者已有近 120 年历史，2021 年售出 400 万辆汽车，而 Lucid 为 125 辆，Rivian 为 920 辆。理想汽车（成立于 2015 年）、蔚来汽车和小鹏汽车（均成立于 2014 年）等中国竞争对手的估值也很高。 In late 2021 the combined market value of six prominent Tesla wannabes hit a stonking $400bn.

;;
;;
;

;Today the six are worth $65bn, and falling (see chart).成立八年的美国公司 Fisker 和成立五年的中国公司 HiPhi 已暂停生产。 On March 25th a crumbling share price caused the trading of Fisker's shares to be suspended and the firm may soon be delisted.高合HiPhi可能正在寻求将自己出售给一家大型中国汽车制造商。 Faraday Future, which sold barely 11 of its upmarket ;EV;s last year, is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy. Lordstown, an American startup founded in 2018 to make electric pickups and ;SUV;s, went bust in 2023.

;

;Even somewhat sturdier firms are struggling. VinFast, a Vietnamese firm which was set up in 2017 and went public last year, briefly—and bafflingly—almost touched $190bn in market value last August. It sold 35,000 ;EV;s in 2023 and is now worth $11bn. Rivian sold 50,000 and is worth a fifteenth of its peak in 2021. Lucid sold 6,000 and is also worth one-fifteenth. Li Auto, Leapmotor, Nio and Xpeng, which delivered over 800,000 cars between them last year, have also seen their share prices shrivel. Only Li turns a profit, mostly because it manufactures nothing but hybrid vehicles; its market value plunged recently after it revealed its first pure ;EV;. Surviving—let alone thriving—in what was meant to be a brave new electric world is proving tough. Which Tesla wannabes, if any, will make it?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It was all meant to be different. Making money from internal combustion engines, whose thousands of moving parts drove up complexity and costs, required carmakers to churn out large volumes. In contrast, the new economics of battery power was supposed to bring down barriers to entry. The electric upstarts, apeing Tesla by styling themselves as tech firms rather than manufacturers, reckoned they could keep costs in check by using simpler designs and reimagining the production process in a way stodgy incumbents could not. Components such as batteries and electric motors can be bought off the shelf, leaving the ;EV;-makers to focus on developing whizzy software that would allow their vehicles to stand out thanks to a better in-car experience, from infotainment to mood lighting. Some companies, like Fisker, simply outsourced the metal-bending.

;

;These advantages have, however, failed to outweigh the old-school ;need for critical mass;. Turning a profit from cars still requires producing perhaps 500,000 vehicles a year. “Scale is vital and manufacturing is hard,” sums up Tu Le of Sino Auto Insights, a consultancy. Though Tesla began as a luxury marque, putting big and pricey batteries in big and pricey cars, it always eyed the mass market. Profits started streaming in only once it overcame the near-death experience— “production hell”, in Mr Musk's words—of trying to churn out high numbers of its cheaper Model 3.

;

;The Tesla wannabes, for their part, have taken too long to start production and are now taking too long to launch new models, says Pedro Pacheco of Gartner, a consultancy. The chances of survival by serving only a high-margin high-price niche are low, notes Philippe Houchois of Jefferies, an investment bank. Just look at the possibly futureless Faraday Future, whose models start at $250,000.

;

;The electric insurgents are waking up to the reality. Their first step is to look downmarket. On March 7th Rivian announced three less expensive models that will start arriving in 2026. Last year Xpeng signed a deal with Didi Global, a Chinese ride-hailing giant, to make cheaper cars and forged a partnership with Volkswagen to make mass-market ;EV;s for China. Nio plans to launch two affordable sub-brands, Alps and Firefly. Even Lucid, whose cars go for as much as $250,000, plans to launch somewhat less exclusive $50,000 models within a few years. In October Leapmotor sold a 20% stake to Stellantis, a mass-market behemoth whose marques include Citroën, Chrysler, Fiat and Peugeot (and whose largest shareholder part-owns ;The Economist;'s parent company), for $1.6bn. The pair will team up to make ;EV;s.

;

;To succeed, these efforts must still produce a competitive product with unique features. Tesla pulled it off by putting technology first. The result was a desirable ;EV; that wasn't cheap but offered a svelte look and decent range; the legacy industry's earlier attempts, such as the Nissan Leaf, were expensive but also ugly and short of juice. Despite a strong tech focus like Tesla, most startups have failed to deliver unique products at competitive cost, as they continue to lack scale, says Patrick Hummel of ;UBS;, a bank. Now the novelty of clever ;EV; technology “has worn off”, adds Becrom Basu of ;LEK;, another consultancy. Good range and other once-cutting-edge tech is considered table stakes, including for incumbent carmakers with considerably beefier manufacturing chops.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;As a result, many of the ;EV; entrants lack unique selling features. The cars made by Rivian and Lucid are technologically unremarkable. Their good looks alone do not justify the hefty price tag. Rivian's cheapest electric pickup costs around $70,000, half as much again as Ford's ;F;-150 Lightning without offering one-and-a-half as much car. In Europe the Lucid Air, a luxury saloon, is significantly pricier than comparable electric ;BMW;s or Mercedes. Fisker's mass-market ;EV;s are also well designed but still cost more than Chinese rivals with similar features, partly because its asset-light outsourcing strategy does not work well for cheaper cars. Why anyone would buy a VinFast remains a mystery; reviews of its ;VF;8 ;SUV; were damning, to put it charitably.

;

;由于产品需求不温不火，许多公司需要更多资金来维持运营。 On March 25th Lucid said it had managed to wangle another $1bn from its biggest investor, Saudi Arabia's sovereign-wealth fund.许多竞争对手就没那么幸运了。截至 2023 年底，Rivian 拥有 94 亿美元的净现金，但还需要数十亿美元来打造更便宜的车型。 Gone are the days when moneymen would throw treasure at any firm with a plausible PowerPoint presentation and an artist's impression of a sleek electric car.在 2021 年之前的几年里，他们投入了数十亿美元，却发现数十亿美元被付诸东流，他们对错过最后期限、令人失望的新模型和不断黯淡的利润前景表示怀疑。 Their second thoughts have not been dispelled by the recent slowdown in growth of ;EV; sales in many countries.现有的汽车制造商没有兴趣拯救叛乱分子。 Mr Hummel of ;UBS; thinks that most of the startups will simply disappear.

;

;The likeliest to survive are the Chinese 。 One reason is that they appear to be the most innovative of the bunch. Nio's upmarket ;EV;s come with the option of battery swapping and, in China at least, a vast network of stations to do it. Drivers can be on their way in minutes without getting out of the car. Bernstein, a broker, considers Xpeng one of the leaders in autonomous-driving technology.

;

;They are also a relative bargain compared with their Western rivals 。 Both Nio and Xpeng, as well as Li Auto, have benefited from an impressive battery supply chain, dominated by Chinese firms like ;CATL;, and steadfast support from central and local governments, notes Mr Le. That in turn has allowed the Chinese companies to keep both their costs and their prices down. The result has been rapid uptake of ;EV;s in their giant domestic market, and with it greater economies of scale.

;

;And another wave of carmaking disruption may be swelling in China, courtesy of ;Chinese big tech;. In 2021 Seres, an established Chinese car company, and Huawei, the closest thing China has to a national tech champion, jointly launched ;AITO;, a new brand dripping with fancy tech. 1 月份，该合资企业交付了 33,000 辆汽车。 On March 28th Xiaomi, which has hitherto made mostly smartphones, launched its first ;SUV;. The car, made by ;BAIC;, a state-owned car giant, and costing as little as $30,000, attracted 90,000 orders in 24 hours.

;

;Xiaomi aims to take on, at least in China, both Tesla and ;BYD;. Alibaba, China's e-commerce behemoth, and ;SAIC;, another big state-owned carmaker, have been producing cars together for two years and sold 38,000 last year. Foxconn, a Taiwanese contract manufacturer better known for assembling iPhones for Apple, many of them in China, aspires to build half the world's ;EV;s for its own brand or others. If Tesla and any other survivors of the current ;EV; shake-out thought they could catch a breath, they should think again. ;■;

;;I;;T is ;WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE;, ;that great coiner, who is given credit for the word.他的英雄之一科利奥兰纳斯将流亡比作一条撤回巢穴的“孤独的龙”。 The Roman general was talking about a physical state: someone who was lonely was simply alone.

;

;Then, thanks to the Romantic poets, the word took on emotional overtones.孤独成为灵魂的一种状态。 For ;William Wordsworth;, who famously “wandered lonely as a cloud”, the natural world offered a reprieve from negative feelings of isolation—a host of daffodils could provide “jocund company”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;By the early 20th century loneliness had come to be considered one of the defining afflictions of urban life. ;Hannah Arendt; lamented that a feeling that was “once a borderline experience usually suffered in certain marginal social conditions like old age, has become an everyday experience of the ever-growing masses”.

;

;Her concerns resonate today, as loneliness is often identified as a serious public-health problem, an epidemic even, that afflicts the elderly and young alike. During the ;covid-19 pandemic; half of Britons reported often feeling lonely; 16 岁至 24 岁之间的人处境最为艰难。智能手机、社交媒体、在线约会和在家工作都被认为是造成疏离感的原因。 Three new books have taken on the subject.

;

;In “All the Lonely People” Sam Carr, a psychologist, collects stories of individuals who feel cut off or forsaken.一名阿富汗青少年难民努力融入萨默塞特的学校。一位八十多岁的老人在养老院里日渐衰弱。 Mr Carr handles this material sensitively, weaving their experiences together with his own, in particular his role as a single parent.

;

;The author evokes the pain of bereavement, heartbreak and childhood trauma and underlines the stigma attached to being withdrawn and friendless.不知何故，这本书并不是一本令人难以忍受的凄凉读物，但你确实想知道孤独是否只是人类处境中不可避免的一部分。 The range of testimonies also suggest that loneliness is not a single feeling so much as a name for a medley of emotions and unsatisfied appetites.

;

;For “Solitude” Netta Weinstein and Thuy-vy Nguyen, two psychology professors, have teamed up with Heather Hansen, an American science writer, to ponder the rewards of time spent alone. They begin with an account of the mythology of solitude created by figures such as Michel de Montaigne, an essayist, and ;Edward Hopper;, a painter. They then draw on laboratory work, interviews and surveys to illuminate how being alone really affects the human psyche.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It is common to treat loneliness and solitude as synonyms, but they不是。 The authors suggest that what is negatively portrayed as one state can be positively reframed as the other. To this end they emphasise the restorative possibilities of being alone and include practical guidance. In a noisy and crowded world, they argue, people should make time to be alone, away from attention-grabbing stimuli.

;

;The book's interviewees mostly regard a lack of company as conducive to autonomy. But this depends on whether solitude is elective or enforced. If it is enforced, as it is for social outcasts and some prisoners, for instance, it is often wretched. Elective solitude, by contrast, above all in natural settings, affords space for reflection. It can open the door to “peak experiences” such as wonder, awe, harmony, even ecstasy. (In a hyper-connected digital age, many readers may not fancy their chances of ever being unplugged long enough to have such experiences.)

;

;Pascal Bruckner sees a world in retreat from sociability in favour of snug seclusion. “The Triumph of the Slippers” is grounded not in research but in the French tradition of witty social criticism. Mr Bruckner, a philosopher and polemicist, dubs the present period “a Great Withdrawal”. As he sees it, the openness of the late 20th century is over, and “the closing of minds and spaces is well under way.” People may like living in “authorised sloppiness”, yet it is hard to imagine heroes and trailblazers wearing dressing gowns: “While it's nice to be comfortable, you can't build a civilisation on softness.”

;

;With a mixture of playfulness and grandiosity, he describes a society where most tasks can be completed without leaving the house. His book overflows with soundbites—the public sphere, for example, is dominated by “orgies of pettiness”—and he peppers his short chapters with references to ;Nietzsche;, Plato and Rousseau.

;

;Though his argument spins off in many directions, Mr Bruckner's main theme is the need for people to relearn the art of intimacy. “Interactive solitude”, enabled by technology, is no substitute for “the great theatre of the world”. Mr Bruckner supplies a checklist for warding off enduring, corrosive feelings of loneliness: “Have we loved enough, given enough, lavished enough, embraced enough?” If these books are right, many readers will find themselves answering “No.” ;■;

;;C;;LIMATE CHANGE; and spiralling conflict are two of the defining features of our time. Each by itself is extremely serious. When they come together, as they increasingly do, the result may be globally devastating.

;

;Climate change increases the risk of conflict. In the Middle East and the Horn of Africa, prolonged droughts are making it harder to eke out livelihoods and uprooting communities. This creates space for extremist groups to exploit the vulnerabilities of local populations and even to provide some of the basic services which governments no longer deliver.; ;With competing groups vying for control of diminishing resources, whole regions can become trapped in a downward spiral of poverty, violence and environmental degradation.

;
;
;
;;
;
;

;Somalia and Iraq are two of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world, as well as recurrent arenas of战争。 In 2023, 6m people faced food insecurity in Somalia after the country's longest recorded drought. Meanwhile, more than half of Iraq's farmland is at risk of desertification. Shortages of water and agricultural land—sources of conflict throughout human history—are certain to get worse.

;

;Yet the world has an opportunity to use this crisis to forge a better future. When faced with a common problem, especially one that threatens their existence, enemies can sometimes be persuaded to bridge long-standing divides. For example, the Indus Waters treaty, which divides river usage between India and Pakistan, remains in place despite many rounds of escalation between the two countries since the treaty was signed 64 years ago.

;

;In some of the worst-hit areas of both Somalia and Iraq, organisations such as the Berghof Foundation, which I run, are working to promote collaboration on environmental challenges. Mediated dialogues between rival groups can build trust and help devise local solutions;,; thereby improving communities' chances of adapting to the climate challenge and creating more prosperous, peaceful futures.

;

;Initiatives such as these, known as environmental peacebuilding, are gathering momentum. They foster co-operation on environmental issues—including renewable energy, nature-reserve management and desalination and irrigation projects—as a way to advance climate action and promote peace simultaneously.

;

;Along the Mali-Niger border, for example, drought is driving nomadic pastoralists into conflict with sedentary farmers. As pastureland becomes increasingly scarce, populations, and with it the need to feed them, are growing rapidly; the population of both countries has more than doubled since 2000. These opposing trends intensify competition for the remaining resources, with women and girls often bearing the brunt of ensuing violence. In Gao and Menaka provinces in Mali and Tillabéri province in Niger, local commissions have been created to prevent and manage disputes over access to fertile land. Their work has helped to integrate environmental protection and conflict resolution. When changes in the natural environment are at the root of conflict, responses to both must go hand in hand.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Environmental peacebuilding needs more support from governments and international organisations. There has been progress in the ;UN;, the European Union and the World Bank, among others, but it is slow and limited. The existing climate-finance system is failing, leaving those most vulnerable behind. According to a ;UN; report, highly fragile countries, such as Sudan and Iraq, receive just over 1% of the funds going to stable countries. This imbalance must be urgently addressed. Firmer guarantees from rich-world governments, such as indemnifying the private sector for some potential losses in high-risk settings, are needed to attract private investment.

;

;The people who profit most from the current state of affairs are; ;those who believe they benefit from instability in climate- and conflict-affected regions. These include Russia's Wagner Group, a mercenary outfit, and far-right nativist parties in richer countries that believe they can gain electorally from what they portray as “waves” of immigrants fleeing these regions.

;

;In order to meet the needs of climate and conflict refugees and to navigate the prevailing anti-immigrant turn in Western countries, development assistance must be better targeted. One of the main drivers of displacement is a country's inability to feed itself. Investing in forms of agriculture that are better suited to the changing climate would enable adaptation, thereby removing the need to seek a life elsewhere. The System of Rice Intensification (;SRI;) is one example of targeted assistance: an “agroecological” approach already in use in parts of Mali, Nigeria and Afghanistan. Its benefits can include tripling grain yield, enhanced micronutrients, higher incomes, water conservation and lower methane emissions.

;

;While critical, development assistance is not enough by itself. Many less developed countries, already suffering disproportionately from climate change, are trapped in a doom loop. Their weak institutions and governance make them more vulnerable to conflict. This leads to environmental degradation and lower productivity, which in turn increase local tensions, and so on.

;

;Governments and international organisations must therefore give more thought to how climate change and conflict interact. Climate change disproportionately affects regions that are already susceptible to conflict. As the problem becomes more acute, its effects will spread well beyond those regions. Treating climate change and conflict as a single threat to global stability, requiring a coherent response, has become a global imperative.

;

;This approach—rather than regarding the worst-hit countries as just “unstable” and therefore unsuitable for investment—will pay dividends later, both for the most vulnerable and for the West. It is not too late.;■;

;;O;;N JANUARY; 22nd 2024 Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, inaugurated the inner sanctum of a new temple in Ayodhya in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. Ram is the idea of India, Ram is the law of India.”

;

;The Hindu-nationalist ideology at the heart of this transformation, and of the agenda of Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (;BJP;), is known as Hindutva, or “Hinduness”.

;

;If, as is expected, the ;BJP; wins re-election in a vote that begins on April 19th, it will probably become ever more central to India's culture and politics. The country's growing economy and its increasing importance in world affairs mean it will also become more relevant to non-Indians. Here's what to read to learn about the origins and core ideas of Hindutva, and what it means for India's political stability, democracy and role in the world.

;;Essentials of Hindutva;. By Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. ;Global Vision; 160 页； £31.50;  ;Bunch of Thoughts;. By Madhav Sadashiv Golwalkar. ;Sahitya Sindhu Prakashana; 536 pages; $18.02;

;

;Adherents of Hindutva say they are merely reviving ancient truths about India's civilisational essence. Yet theirs is a modern religious nationalism that gained influence in the early 20th century as opponents of British rule looked for sources of national identity to rally around. A key moment was the founding in 1925 of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (;RSS;), an all-male volunteer outfit inspired by European fascist movements. The group sought to instil in its members the unity and discipline required to build a Hindu nation. It also advocated violence. The man who killed Mohandas Gandhi in 1948 was a member of the ;RSS;. The group's understanding of Hinduness was partly based on the ideas of ;VD; Savarkar, whose book “Essentials of Hindutva” popularised the term. Savarkar, writing while he was in jail for anti-British activities, defined Hinduism as a cultural identity that excludes Muslims and Christians. In “Bunch of Thoughts”, a collection of speeches, ;MS; Golwalkar, who led the ;RSS; from 1940 to 1973, elaborated on Savarkar's ideas in a more populist style. He espoused the idea of Hindu India as a teacher to the world and believed that only Hindus could be true Indians. Although the ;RSS; has since tried to sound more tolerant, Gowalkar's speeches remain an important source for Hindu nationalism. Gowalkar himself is still revered as “Guru-ji”.

;

;;Messengers of Hindu Nationalism: How the RSS Reshaped India;.作者：沃尔特·安徒生 (Walter Andersen) 和施里达尔·D·达姆勒 (Shridhar D. Damle)。 ;Hurst; 320页； $35 and £30;

;

;When India wrote its constitution after independence in 1947 the ;RSS;'s campaign to define the country as a Hindu nation lost out to advocates of a secular conception of India. The group's violent bent confined it to the fringe of politics for decades. Based on interviews with ;RSS; leaders, members and allies, this book explains how it nevertheless expanded its influence, especially from the 1980s onwards. The ;BJP;, its political wing, and Mr Modi, who was an ;RSS; activist long before he became a party politician, played a central role.

;

;;Modi's India: Hindu Nationalism and the Rise of Ethnic Democracy;. By Christophe Jaffrelot. Translated by Cynthia Schoch. ;Princeton University Press; 656 pages; $27.95 and £30;

;

;What happens to a highly diverse, secular democracy like India if its government subscribes to a majoritarian ideology? Christophe Jaffrelot, a political scientist at King's College London, has worked on Hindu nationalism for decades. In this book he writes that Mr Modi, first in his home state of Gujarat and then at the national level, combined Hindutva with a welfarist developmental agenda to win political majorities before setting about capturing institutions such as the courts and harassing opponents in the press, academia and civil society. Prominent adherents of Hindutva, including Mr Modi, have recently begun to claim that their ideology has unified Indians of all religions and restored their pride in their cultural heritage. On the contrary, says Mr Jaffrelot: it has divided society and relegated non-Hindus, particularly Muslims and Christians, to the status of second-class citizens. They must accept the primacy of the majority or face exclusion and violence. If you read only one book on this list, make it this one.

;

;;Hindu Nationalism in the Indian Diaspora: Transnational Politics and British Multiculturalism;. By Edward TG Anderson. ;Oxford University Press; 434 页； $39.95.赫斯特； £30;

;

;The Indian ;diaspora; is bigger and more influential than that of any other country.因此，印度也输出其政治也就不足为奇了。莫迪先生在美国、英国和澳大利亚为崇拜者举行了集会。 2022 年 9 月，英国中部地区的莱斯特发生了英国印度教徒和南亚裔穆斯林之间的骚乱，让人想起印度城市的社区骚乱。在这本书中，历史学家爱德华·安德森探讨了散居海外的印度教民族主义情绪如何影响当地政治和英国多元文化主义的运作。 Despite his focus on just one country, many of his insights apply to other places with large groups of Indian-origin immigrants.

;

;;Love Jihad and Other Fictions: Simple Facts to Counter Viral Falsehoods;. By Sreenivasan Jain, Mariyam Alavi and Supriya Sharma. ;Aleph Book Company; 208 pages; 485 rupees;

;

;Beyond official ideology exists an entire ecosystem of Hindutva-adjacent conspiracy theories and propaganda. They are spread largely through social media, especially WhatsApp, which nearly 500m Indians use. Prominent politicians and celebrities often amplify them. The messages usually centre on vague suggestions of threats to Hindus and their religion. A notorious one is the bogey of “love jihad”, which imagines a systematic effort by Muslim men to seduce Hindu women, convert them, impregnate them and even lure them into committing terrorist acts. Often accompanied by calls for Hindus to defend themselves, the messages whip up hatred and can incite violence. In this book, three Indian journalists debunk the most common WhatsApp conspiracies. Their aim is to equip fellow Indians with facts, which they can use to educate friends and family members who have begun to believe falsehoods. It may not serve that purpose: the truth often does not persuade. But for outsiders the book provides insight into the toxic side of Indian social media and their role in mass mobilisation.
